quiz.title: Graph to Equation Conversion
quiz.subtitle: Unit 5 Quiz 1: Writing Equations from Graphs
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Deriving Linear Equations from Graphical Representations

questions.question: Based on the graph shown, which equation represents the line?
questions.explanation: From the graph: line passes through (0, -2) and (2, 2). Slope = (2 - (-2))/(2 - 0) = 4/2 = 2. y-intercept = -2. So $y = 2x - 2$.

questions.question: What is the equation of the horizontal line shown in the graph?
questions.explanation: Horizontal lines have equation $y = \text{constant}$. The line crosses the y-axis at 3, so $y = 3$.

questions.question: The graph shows a line with negative slope. Which equation matches the graph?
questions.explanation: From graph points (1, 4) and (3, 0): Slope = (0 - 4)/(3 - 1) = -4/2 = -2. Using point-slope: $y - 4 = -2(x - 1) \Rightarrow y = -2x + 6$.

questions.question: Which equation represents the vertical line shown?
questions.explanation: Vertical lines have equation $x = \text{constant}$. The line crosses the x-axis at -4, so $x = -4$.

questions.question: From the graph shown, determine the equation of the line.
questions.explanation: Line passes through (0, -1) and (2, 0). Slope = (0 - (-1))/(2 - 0) = 1/2. y-intercept = -1. So $y = \frac{1}{2}x - 1$.

questions.question: Which equation matches the line shown in the graph?
questions.explanation: Line passes through (0, 4) and (2, -2). Slope = (-2 - 4)/(2 - 0) = -6/2 = -3. y-intercept = 4. So $y = -3x + 4$.

questions.question: Based on the graph, what is the equation of the line?
questions.explanation: The graph shows a horizontal line crossing the y-axis at 4. Horizontal lines have equation $y = \text{constant}$, so $y = 4$.

questions.question: The line in the graph passes through the origin. Which equation is correct?
questions.explanation: Line passes through (0, 0) and (3, -3). Slope = (-3 - 0)/(3 - 0) = -3/3 = -1. With y-intercept = 0, equation is $y = -x$.

questions.question: Determine the equation from the graph shown.
questions.explanation: Line passes through (0, 1) and (3, 3). Slope = (3 - 1)/(3 - 0) = 2/3. y-intercept = 1. So $y = \frac{2}{3}x + 1$.

questions.question: Which equation represents the line shown in the final graph?
questions.explanation: The graph shows a vertical line crossing the x-axis at 2. Vertical lines have equation $x = \text{constant}$, so $x = 2$.

scoreMessages.90: Exceptional! You master extracting equations from all types of graphs: positive/negative slopes, horizontal/vertical lines, and fractional slopes.
scoreMessages.70: Strong skills! Focus on distinguishing between horizontal (y=constant) and vertical (x=constant) lines, and calculating fractional slopes accurately.
scoreMessages.50: Good progress. Practice: 1) Identifying intercepts clearly, 2) Calculating slope with fractions, 3) Recognizing special cases (horizontal/vertical).
scoreMessages.0: Start with identifying y-intercept from where line crosses y-axis. Then find two clear points to calculate slope using rise/run.
